paragraphs.name: 18a4
paragraphs.text: I wonder if the difference is due to the gender of the salesperson doing the talking. About a month ago there wa a fascinating report about two professors who restaged segments of the Trump-Clinton debates, but reversed the gender of the candidates. It turned out that Trump’s words and mannerisms presented by a woman were far more persuasive and far…

paragraphs.name: ff3f
paragraphs.text: Very interesting! This reminds on one fact from buyers perspctive. People are more likely to buy something from women if the value is up to 3/4 of their monthly income. In higher value male reps have better conversion. One insurance company made this study couple a years ago… It would be interesting to see these numbers today.

9b3220b4aa5.title: The truth is that the “rules of selling” were written for a product oriented and old fashioned…

paragraphs.name: 42ef
paragraphs.text: The truth is that the “rules of selling” were written for a product oriented and old fashioned world. People hate being sold to and this is starting to change those so called rules. From your data it sounds like women who are not powered up by the testosterone of commissions are responding better than men to this trend.

paragraphs.text: In my experience, women tend to be more empathetic with prospects, and therefore, seem to have more success in closing (and I’m not just talking about my wife). Talking through the prospect’s pain points and being more interested in cultivating a relationship with the prospect may lead to these stats around women talking more. This study doesn’t…

paragraphs.name: c4dd
paragraphs.text: Chris, it’s great to see some sort of measurement going on in real, actual call conversations with sales reps. As someone who wakes up everyday to work to see more women in sales and sales leadership roles in companies that are traditionally male-majority on their sales teams — I’m not interested in who’s better because there is room for both great…

Great writeup. Having listened to calls with both men and women as reps, I’ve noticed the following trend: Prospects often won’t take a woman’s “word for it” as readily as they will a man’s (especially when it comes to technical capabilities of a software). There’s a tendency for prospects to ask women to repeat something, or to ask questions that…

paragraphs.text: I would bet that women more often rephrase and confirm what their prospects just told them and a significant amount of the time they’re talking is reaffirming and showing that they have listened to the customer by recapping their needs, wants, and concerns.

paragraphs.text: One thing I don’t see here is the data around which of the men and women had closes correlated against these 3 metrics. It could be that the women with higher close rates are not the same as those who are interrupting or talking more etc. It could be a larger majority of women, over an average, show these traits but the outlier women who are below…

paragraphs.text: Chris, what industries were you following? The industry, to me makes a difference. If the sales people from an industry is male dominated, then I would expect the women in sales in that industry to be of a better quality, thus advance the sales process and close more sales.

paragraphs.text: Cool Post!

I wonder if these statistics hold whether the customer is a man or a woman. My personal intuition is that an account executive would close deals more easily when talking to a customer of the opposite gender... Could be interesting to check it!

4612954e1ace.title: Agreed — there are many variables to the “sales effectiveness equation.”

paragraphs.name: 16fa
paragraphs.text: Agreed — there are many variables to the “sales effectiveness equation.” The data and science simply point us in the right direction on our qualitative search.

ca0360ab05d6.title: A couple suggestions: 1) perform correlation analysis within each gender to see if men/women who…

paragraphs.name: d94c
paragraphs.text: A couple suggestions: 1) perform correlation analysis within each gender to see if men/women who follow the “rules” of sales actually do better than men/women who don’t. Maybe the “rules” are wrong… 2) Check out Robert Cialdini’s book “Influence” for evidence based principles of persuasion. Maybe the women are following these alternative “sales rules…

ed48bc976f6f.title: Or it could be that what’s being said makes a difference.

paragraphs.name: f4a1
paragraphs.text: Or it could be that what’s being said makes a difference. Women may ask more questions to uncover the prospect’s pain, or may verbally empathize more, or may build better rapport. Hard to measure those with this data.
Then again, it could be just the fact that they’re not throwing around Nerf toys that causes them to sell…

paragraphs.text: This is really interesting! Quick question — does your data set have information about whether the prospects were women or men?
I’m curious if there was any correlation between conversion percentages and men-men, men-women, women-women, and women-men sales calls.
